intro: Leucopogon secundiflorus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved heath, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes shrubs and evergreen plants adapted to acidic soils. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and evergreen, providing year-round structure in the landscape. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks.
